unnormalised: Delhi: Concerns are rising among contractors and builders across the NCR region as cement prices are projected to climb by 15% in the next quarter. Industry insiders are attributing this hike to rising fuel costs and increased demand due to the ongoing construction boom. This will inevitably translate to higher costs for homebuyers, especially for properties under construction.
normalised: Delhi: Concerns are rising among contractors and builders across the N-C-R region as cement prices are projected to climb by fifteen percent in the next quarter. Industry insiders are attributing this hike to rising fuel costs and increased demand due to the ongoing construction boom. This will inevitably translate to higher costs for home buyers, especially for properties under construction.

unnormalised: "The impact will be significant," says Rajesh Sharma, a leading civil engineer in Gurgaon. "A typical 2BHK flat requiring approx. 500 bags of cement will see its cost increase by at least Rs. 7500, adding to the overall financial burden on buyers."
normalised: "The impact will be significant," says Rajesh Sharma, a leading civil engineer in Gurgaon. "A typical two B-H-K flat requiring approximately five hundred bags of cement will see its cost increase by at least rupee seven thousand five hundred, adding to the overall financial burden on buyers."

unnormalised: According to data from the National Real Estate Development Council (NAREDCO), the average cost of construction materials accounts for approx. 40-50% of the total project cost. The rising cement prices are expected to further squeeze profit margins for developers, potentially leading to delays in project completion or compromised construction quality.
normalised: According to data from the National Real Estate Development Council (N-A-R-E-D-C-O), the average cost of construction materials accounts for approximately forty to fifty percent of the total project cost. The rising cement prices are expected to further squeeze profit margins for developers, potentially leading to delays in project completion or compromised construction quality.

unnormalised: Adding to the woes, steel prices have also witnessed a surge recently. A tonne of steel, which was previously priced at around Rs. 65,000, is now hovering around Rs. 72,000. This will further exacerbate the problems being faced by builders.
normalised: Adding to the woes, steel prices have also witnessed a surge recently. A ton of steel, which was previously priced at around rupee sixty five thousand, is now hovering around rupee seventy two thousand. This will further exacerbate the problems being faced by builders.

unnormalised: “Earlier, we were able to manage the cost because of the stable rate of cement and steel, but now the situation is a bit alarming as the cost is frequently changing”, says Mr. Kapoor, the owner of a local building firm, he goes on to say “this will affect the smaller construction projects, and they might need to pause or slow down on the construction”
normalised: “Earlier, we were able to manage the cost because of the stable rate of cement and steel, but now the situation is a bit alarming as the cost is frequently changing”, says Mister Kapoor, the owner of a local building firm, he goes on to say “this will affect the smaller construction projects, and they might need to pause or slow down on the construction”

unnormalised: The government has so far remained silent on the issue. Industry experts suggest that intervention from the government in the form of tax relief or subsidies could help alleviate the burden on the construction sector. Otherwise, the dream of affordable housing for many Indians could become even more distant.
normalised: The government has so far remained silent on the issue. Industry experts suggest that intervention from the government in the form of tax relief or subsidies could help alleviate the burden on the construction sector. Otherwise, the dream of affordable housing for many Indians could become even more distant.

unnormalised: Ultimately, it's the end consumer who will bear the brunt of these rising costs. Whether it's the young couple looking to buy their first home or the small business owner building a new shop, everyone will feel the pinch. It's time for stakeholders to come together to find sustainable solutions to mitigate the impact of these escalating construction costs.
